segments.text: Let's talk about the effect of the Korean War, or about the Korean War itself.
Why weren't you called into the Korean War?
I was.
But I didn't go.
Then why isn't it here?
You were called, but you didn't go?
I got orders.
Oh, tell me about that.
I'm full of these little strange things.
That's just after the time that I had joined the 420th Engineer Brigade.
Yeah, right.
I had joined the 420th Engineer Brigade shortly.
1951, yeah.
Okay, and it seemed to me like it was like in May or June, somewhere in the middle of the summer.
The war broke out in June 1950.
Yeah, but I'm... Korean War?
Mm-hmm, mm-hmm.
Well, anyhow, I joined the 420th in, like, May or June of 51.
Yeah.
And in November, I got orders to report to Fort Belvoir, which was a Korean call.
Okay.
I knew that I was not supposed to be called as an individual out of an organized reserve unit.
That was policy then.
They did not call individuals out of reserve units for active duty.
I knew it was a mistake.
But anyhow, I had this order to report to Fort Belvoir.
So I went on and went to Fort Hood and took my physical.
But in the meantime, I had applied to Texas Military District to clarify my status.
but I wasn't really ready to go back on active duty.

But anyhow, the upshot of the whole thing was that when the Adjutant General in Washington asked for clarification on my status for recall, they overlooked the order that I had been assigned to the 420th Engineer Brigade.
I see.
So I wasn't available for recall, and the order was revoked.
But I went so far as to take my physical to go to Fort Belvoir.
So when I got that resolved, well, that took me completely out of the Korean War.
I see.
In other words, if you would have not been assigned to the 420, I think you would have...
I would have been in the Korean War.
Mm-hmm.
Yeah.
Well, what were your feelings about that, about not going?
I didn't want to get back in...

in that skirmish over there I really I really didn't want to go back on active duty but first I was fulfilling my duty in a reserve status and this was the time you know this was this is the way you could fulfill your duty now if the 420th had been called I had no compunction I mean that that was my unit yeah but uh as an individual I I didn't want to there's a you know you just get
kicked into a strange unit in combat or wherever, you're sort of lost.
Yeah.
But the 420th been called, I had not a word to say.
Well, what were your feelings?
There were very few reserve units called during the Korean War.
What was your feeling toward that?
Did you think that Truman should call up the reserves or should use draft or should draft young men or what?
Well, I was on a panel up at the War College to discuss that particular feature.
Really?
When was this?
In the 1960s?
No, this is when I went to the War College here at, up here, right here, 1969.
Yeah.
They had a panel of reservists, and that question was posed to the reservists as whether the
whether the morale of the reserves would have been enhanced or whatever from calling reserve units to Korean War or whether we thought we should not have been called or whatever.
The consensus of that panel was that it was a mistake not to use the reserves for what they were intended for.
Not that anybody wanted to go to combat.
Not that anybody wanted to get in the war.
But they were paid for that.
Tax monies were used for that.
And it was the consensus of that group that the reserve program feels that when a need is there, they ought to be used.
Yeah.
And most of these then were other, at this conference, were other reserve generals?
That's right.
That's correct.
In fact, it was a school, it was a two-week conference for general officers.
So this panel was made up of reserve and National Guard generals.
And it was just about unanimous opinion that they thought a mistake was made in not utilizing reserves for what they were intended for.
And did you think the same with the Vietnam War?
Well, by that time, I had a little different opinion of the Vietnam War because... Because this was right during the heat of the Vietnam War in 1969.
Well, that's right.
And Johnson refused to call up the reserves.
That's right.
The Vietnam War and the Korean War were similar, but I think we got into the
Vietnam War a little bit differently than we got in the Korean War.
And for that reason, I felt a little bit different about the Korean War.
I mean, yeah, the Vietnam War.
But the principle that we talked about, I think, still held.
I think when troops are needed, then they ought to turn to the reserve.
Because that's what the reserve is for.
And I just think that
And any time we have any kind of emergency, I just think Johnson was just completely off base and not using the reserves more than they were used.
And I think his was strictly political.
He was strictly political.
And I don't think that kind of decision needs to be made on a political basis.
Well, speaking of political and military decisions, let's talk about your views on getting back to Korea, back on the Korean War.
What did you think of the idea of a stalemate war?
I don't think we ought to ever get into one.
We don't go in to win.
What did you think about the political decision to fire General MacArthur?
and not to strike the bases, the Chinese bases north of the Yalu River, and to continue a divided Korea?
Well, I think that MacArthur knew more about what we ought to do over there than some of the politicians in Washington.
And I personally think that
It's difficult to kill an ant bed by catching them every time they come out around the hole.
I think you need to get in the hole to get them.
But I think MacArthur was wrong in being insubordinate to his spirit, even though he knew a heck of a lot more than his spirit did.
That situation has just grated on me ever since it happened.
And I'm terribly surprised that a man of his military career would get into the situation that he got into.
Now, I think there are a lot of things behind it.
He was being sniped at by a lot of people that didn't like him, who had an ear to the president.
I think that's without question.
But our
military structure has always been built on absolute devotion to duty, absolute subordination to superiors.
And I cannot, by any means, support MacArthur or anybody else taking the action that they did, from what I can read.
I don't know what was going on.
I can see the reports.
But just a general idea.
That's right.
But I think we ought to gone ask those boogers and got them out of there.
There was no way to win like we went.
And I totally agree with MacArthur that there's no substitution for victory in war.
You don't go into war to push somebody back.
You go into war to win the dadgum thing.
If you're going to get in the war, you ought to go to win it.

okay then let's let's relate that to vietnam is that the way you felt about vietnam that's right i don't think we ought to have been there like we were that they let to my way of thinking and again what i can read we went over there to advise them whether that's really what we went for or not i don't know but that's the role we went with and then we had people there and we just got involved in the darn thing but
Here again, I don't have any feeling that we ought to have gone there without trying to win it.
Now, do you blame losing that war on politicians or on the military?
I don't know which politicians.
And here again, rightfully so.
I think our top...
Decision makers ought to be the civilians.
I like our system.
But I think our military people did a great job, but they had their hands tied behind them.
And I don't think we ought to go in any war without swinging with both hands.
I don't think you can blame that on the military at all.
At least I don't.
Who do you think holds the power in America, then?
Who holds it?
Do you think it's the people or do you think it's the elites?
Well, it's the bigwigs in Washington and not necessarily the elected bigwigs.
people that are ingrained up there that are running that place, and I don't think it's all congressional people.
What do you mean?
Who is it then?
Oh, it's the appointed people that are in the civil service jobs and the high echelons of appointed jobs.
Of course, see, they're not
They're not subject to the whims of people at all.
The big high civil service people and this sort of thing.
We've got too much of that, in my opinion.
You can't touch them.
Let's go back to your career.
In the 1960s, all of a sudden,
You get all kinds of service schools.
I noticed you didn't have very much.
Oh, from 44, you have one.
And then you don't have another one until 1962.
But then from 62 to 69, it's just one right after another.
Well, two things.
One, I began to get in a more responsible job in the military and in the highway department.
I had more latitude to go to those schools and I had more desire to go because each one of them was enhancing my education and my command abilities and there were lots of opportunities to go.
There was uh that's during the time they were
promoting the reserves, and as I said a while ago, lots of schools, lots of armories, lots of emphasis on the reserve.
And there was just lots of schools that were available to me, and I took the opportunity to go.
It not only entailed travel over the United States, but met and associated with many, many people that I got as much out of as I did out of school.
Right.
Right.
What do you think were the most important schools?
I noticed you have chemical and biological weapons.
There were a few of those schools that I was sort of expected to go to.
That chemical and biological out at Dugway was one of them.
About that time, the nerve gases and the various exotic...
warfare techniques were coming into prominence.
They wanted us to know about them.
Another one is the police school over at, I forgot what place it was now.
You mean the disturbance orientation course?
Yeah.
I was going to ask you about that at Fort Gordon, Georgia.
Right.
Yeah.
That was during the times of strikes and violence.
That was a response, would you say that was a response to the civil disturbances of the mid-1960s?
That's correct.
They were trying to educate the reserves to fulfill their role in case they were needed.
And those schools were pretty much mandatory.
Mandatory for the leaders in the Army?
Right, that's correct.
And they were established for that purpose, for
They are established by the politicians or by the military?
By the military to deal with their role in foiling riots and handling disturbances and this sort of thing.
Well, tell me about that.
What did they teach you?
Oh, they taught you riot control.
They taught you the various chemicals that were available for riot control.
They taught you...
many things where you need to use restraints, what to do in case of violence, what to do if people had to be restrained and kept pinned up, so to speak.
And they just ran the gamut as far as those things that you would do as a leader.
to direct your troops.
Did they bring in military officers, or did they bring in police who had been in these riots?
Both.
Both.
A lot of our instructors were police who had been actually involved.
As I remember, one of our instructors was the police commissioner of New York City.
Yeah, he'd been involved.
Golly, you couldn't have found a person who had more.

actual experience, but they brought in people that had actually been involved and told you of things that had happened to them and how they had handled them and policies and techniques and procedures, and it was most interesting.
Sounds like that would be fascinating.
What type of people were these?
I mean, the teachers, were they, what could you describe them?
Is there any way that you could categorize all of these people?
Besides experienced?
No.
There were some military.
There were some military instructors and then some of the, I'd say, outside PAC people.
But they were, I would call them professionals.
I can sure tell you that.
Because the Army went out and got the best that they could find.
They did not spare expense.
And there were not only military people in the school, there were outsiders, like police chiefs and police commissioners.
I mean, there were students in the school, too, along with military.
Oh, students.
Yes, along with military.
So community governments or city governments would join up there with the military.
That's correct.
That seems to be a much better idea.
Oh, it was.
I thought it was great.
The concept of it was terrific.
I'll tell you what it made you wish that you never got involved in one of those civil commotions because they can be most frustrating.
Yeah.
And the main reason is you're pitting the man that lives here against the man that lives right over there.
Yeah.
If you've got a reservist here and the man across the street is in a civil commotion, this fellow has got

in some cases got to kill him hopefully not but here you're pitting neighbors against neighbors and that takes some trying now these this is 1969 these were rather angry years did the instructors use much rhetoric oh yeah they you know they they leveled with you I mean they they didn't pull any punches
In fact, you got the feeling they were trying to scare you to death.
Really?
About what?
Scare you about what?
Well, the situations you could get in.
Oh, I see.
And the importance of coolness and the importance of using proper techniques and the importance of not prolonging or provoking these situations.

You know, that's one of the most important things in these deals is to do the thing that you need to do to tend to cool it, but do it in a manner that you don't provoke and prolong and make it bigger and worse.
And it doesn't take much in a fit of fury, you know, to just blow the thing wide open.
Sure, sure.
So they used...
Well, they were, they just didn't miss any opportunities, I tell you for sure.
Okay, let's go back to your military career that night.

You know, in every career, highway department, teaching, or military career, people feel that they had accomplishments, and they also feel that there were some things that they would have liked to accomplish, but they just didn't have the time or something, that there were some shortcomings.
What would you consider were the accomplishments of your military career, especially in the reserves over the last 10 or 20 years?
The one big thing that I look back with is a great deal of satisfaction in the reserve.
At the time I was appointed brigade commander, we had grown to where we were
a unit to be reckoned with.
We were a significant part of the reserve program.
Up till that time, we had been growing and we had been getting a little bigger.
We started out with a little force of two, three hundred people.
We would work hard all during the year to aim at a couple of weeks at summer camp.
We'd get on a bus and go to summer camp, and we'd listen to instruction, or we'd watch demonstrations.
And then as we got a little bit more capable, we'd get on equipment, and we'd get our hands dirty, so to speak.
Up until the time that I took over the brigade and went as a whole to a summer camp,
And we'd have to try to find enough stuff for 400, 600, 1500 people to do constructively at one location.
And we went to Walters Air Force Base four times.
We went to Fort Hood once.
And we'd gone to Fort Polk about 10 or 11 times.
We were just bulging them out at the seams.
We'd come in there with 1,500, 1,600 people and have a real hard time finding work enough to keep all that many people busy for two weeks and then just pass out of the camp.
So the first year that I took over the brigade, we went back to Fort Polk.
And I, along with some of my staff officers, got to looking at, are we doing all we can do to
to promote this unit and make it proficient and still do something constructive for the Army installations.
And I decided that we had outgrown a camp.
We had outgrown all going together.
It was ideal because you could see every one of your troops.
You could see all that they were doing.
You could have a parade.
You could have a party, you know.
So I journeyed down to Fourth Army along with my training officer and executive officer.
And we sat down with their training people and told them of our concept that we had outgrown a one-unit summer camp.
And we proposed to them that we diversify ourselves and go anywhere in the Fourth Army that

they could accommodate us at different times and split this brigade up for summer camp and let the staff officers of the brigade go and satellite on these units and watch them operate, supervise them, reconnoiter them, but operate like we'd do if we were a brigade on active duty with maybe a battalion over here and a
separate company off over here and a group up yonder and, you know, just go here, there, and yonder where we could really get some good work.
And boy, they threw up a hand and said, you can't do any such thing like that.
He said, you know, you've got to go where you can look at your troops.
And I said, look, we've got capable staff officers that can go out and be the listen and watch these units work.

And I said, that way for 12 months, we'll not sit in that armory over there, but I'll send a couple of engineers to Fort Bliss, and we'll get with a post engineer, and we'll come up with things that this company can do and that battalion can do and this one can do, and we'll do the field work.
We'll do the engineering work.
We'll do the plan work.
And then when we get ready to send them out there, all you've got to do is furnish some money
or to buy the materials, and if we need to ship equipment, whatever.
But we'll send a contingent out there.
Then we'll send another one up to Fort Bliss, and another one to Chaffee, and another one to Polk, and, you know, wherever, and the whole Fourth Army.
And they thought that we had lost our minds.
They said, you can't control it.
You can't, you can't, the thing will just completely get away from you.
And we convinced them we could.
And I mean, we did.
And I want you to read what this deputy Army commander said in this final evaluation about that sort of thing.
But we convinced them.
And the next year, I'm telling you, we were all over the 4th Army area.
We sent people to the engineering, the diving school at Fort Eustis, Virginia.
firefighters out to the A&M Fire School.
We just sent people wherever they needed to be and you never saw morale rise in your life.
They were so tired of going to Fort Poles and running off out in the woods and building the trail or building a bridge or whatever and we just really had a ball and
We got more compliments from the Army staff about that operation, and we did that for the full rest of the time, and they're still doing it to a great degree.
So they're continuing this program now?
They have.
It sold itself.
